title-group.article-title: School Leaders’ Perceptions About Incompetent Teachers
title-group.subtitle: Implications for Supervision and Evaluation

author-notes.corresp: Bret G. Range, University of Wyoming, Education, Room 310, 1000 E. University Ave., Laramie, WY 82071, USA Email: brange@uwyo.edu

permissions.copyright-holder: National Association of Secondary School Principals

abstract.p: This study explored Wyoming school leaders’ perceptions about the traits of incompetent teachers, strategies used to work with incompetent teachers, and the barriers to their dismissal. Most importantly, this study differentiated how principals and superintendents viewed incompetency issues. Some major findings include school leaders’ beliefs that classroom management problems were an indicator of incompetence, counseling to leave the profession was a strategy used with incompetent teachers, and teacher unions were a barrier to their dismissal.

body.p: Research suggests the most persuasive factor in increasing student achievement is teacher effectiveness (Owings et al., 2006; Rutledge, Harris, & Ingle, 2010; Sanders & Rivers, 1996; Stronge, 2002; Wright, Horn, & Sanders, 1997). Although variables such as class size, per pupil expenditures, curriculum, and student demographics all contribute to student learning, the strength of instruction delivered by teachers is the most critical factor (Leithwood, Seashore Louis, Anderson, & Wahlstrom, 2004; Stronge & Hindman, 2003). However, how to define teacher effectiveness and how to accurately measure it are polarizing debates (Armour-Garb, 2009; Futernick, 2010; Jacob & Lefgren, 2008). In fact, Stronge, Ward, and Grant (2011) stated that “effectiveness is an elusive concept to define when we consider the complex task of teaching and the multitude of contexts in which teachers work” (p. 340). Nevertheless, policy makers are highly vested in defining teaching effectiveness as evidenced by the emphasis on teaching quality within the No Child Left Behind Act of 2001 (2002) and this interest will not likely diminish (Armour-Garb, 2009; Stronge, n.d.). For example, states that applied for Race to the Top funds had to report the percentage of teachers rated competent in each district, indentify how information from observations was used to evaluate teachers, and describe how tenure was acquired (American Recovery and Reinvestment Act [ARRA], 2009; Chait, 2010; Stoelinga, 2011).

Although teachers have the greatest impact on student achievement, school leaders also have a powerful, albeit indirect, impact on student success (Leithwood et al., 2004; Nettles & Herrington, 2007). The primary method by which principals influence student achievement is by helping teachers improve their practice, a process termed instructional leadership (Green, 2010; Nolan & Hoover, 2008; Stronge, n.d.; Zepeda, 2012). Within this role, principals formatively supervise teachers by routinely visiting classrooms to collect data on performance and use data to summatively evaluate teachers (Cooper, Ehrensal, & Bromme, 2005; Pratt, 1996). Both the supervision and evaluative processes work in tandem as principals use multiple data sources to evaluate teacher effectiveness (Range, Scherz, Holt, & Young, 2011; Stronge, n.d.; Zepeda, 2007). In the end, the primary role of evaluation is “to provide evidence to support recommendations for retention or nonretention” (Pratt, 1996, . 32) and to ensure teachers are held to rigorous, common standards (Nolan & Hoover, 2008; Stronge, n.d.).

One of the most important roles of school leaders as they undertake supervision and evaluation duties is the identification of incompetent or ineffective teachers. However, researchers have argued that little is known about how incompetent teachers are identified, what procedures are in place to remediate or dismiss them, and how school leaders’ views differ based on their roles as principals or superintendents (Wragg, Haynes, Wragg, & Chamberlin, 1999; Yariv, 2004). This study attempts to fill this void and explores school leaders’ (principals and superintendents) perceptions about teacher incompetency issues. Attempting to clearly define ineffective teaching characteristics and identify barriers to dismissing incompetent teachers are important research endeavors within the context of whole school accountability (Platt, Tripp, Ogden, & Fraser, 2000; Reeves, 2002, 2004; The New Teacher Project, 2010; Tucker, 1997).

sec.title: Literature Review
sec.p: The literature review that follows is designed to frame the problem of teacher incompetency. The review begins by providing a background for the problem and then progresses into defining effective teaching and incompetency within the literature and within statute and case law. Additionally, a description of administrative strategies used with incompetent teachers is presented. The literature review concludes by highlighting barriers to dismissing incompetent teachers and provides a context for the study.

sec.title: Background
sec.p: The theoretical backdrop for this study is grounded in the role of school leaders as formative supervisors and summative evaluators of teachers (Green, 2010; Ovando & Ramirez, 2007; Zepeda, 2007). The distinct purposes of formative supervision and summative evaluation tend to confuse both educators and policy makers (Nolan & Hoover, 2008). Supervision hinges on the ability of principals to provide constructive feedback to teachers to improve their practice (Kimball, 2002; Zepeda, 2012). Conversely, evaluation’s primary purpose is to judge teachers’ competency in relation to standards (Zepeda, 2012). Despite these differing frameworks, most school districts funnel both supervision and evaluation into the same process, and principals must understand how to connect both to make teacher evaluation meaningful (Green, 2010; Nolan & Hoover, 2008). Stronge (n.d.) connected supervision and evaluation by stating that “teacher evaluation is, first, about documenting the quality of teacher performance; then, its focus shifts to help teachers improve their performance as well as holding them accountable for their work” (p. 1). In the end, when supervision and evaluation are linked, they serve two purposes: (a) teacher improvement and (b) individual accountability (Wise, Darling-Hammond, McLaughlin, & Bernstein, 1984).

As school leaders undertake supervisory and evaluative roles, many identify incompetent teachers as a significant problem in schools (Last & Murphy, 1998; Menuey, 2005; Platt et al., 2000). Incompetent teachers present a host of problems for school and district leaders, such as producing poor student achievement results, distracting other faculty members, and consuming large amounts of administrative time (Painter, 2000; Yariv, 2004). However, when asked to define the traits of incompetent teachers under an evaluative lens, school leaders’ descriptions become vague (Platt et al., 2000). A primary reason for this is that school leaders do not like to admit they are supervising incompetent teachers and are reluctant to confront them (Fuhr, 1993; Haefele, 1992). School leaders “will do their utmost to hide their shortcomings. Common feelings of frustration and shame are obscured by a layer of denial and false description” (Yariv, 2004, p. 151).

Interestingly, Jacob and Lefgren (2006) found that principals, when allowed to remain anonymous, could identify ineffective teachers based on correlations between classroom observations and students’ test scores. Internationally, Wragg et al. (1999) found that headmasters were also perceptive in identifying “a cluster of factors” that signaled incompetency. Finally, although researchers have highlighted principals’ perceptions about incompetent teachers (Blacklock, 2002; Brieschke, 1986; Last & Murphy, 1998; Phillips & Young, 1997; Torff & Sessions, 2005), limited studies focus on how superintendents view teacher incompetency issues. A likely explanation for this is principals conduct summative teacher evaluations while superintendents may play a supportive role in the process (Weisberg, Sexton, Mulhern, & Keeling, 2010).

sec.title: Effective Teaching
sec.p: Scholars argue there is little consensus within the education community about how to define effective teaching (Ingersoll, 2001; Lewis et al., 1999; Popp, Grant, & Stronge, 2011). Researchers have equated teacher effectiveness to student achievement results or by positive supervisor evaluations of teachers’ performance (Stronge & Hindman, 2003). According to Stronge et al. (2011), a primary debate about teaching competency includes whether teaching qualifications, teaching processes, products of teaching, or a combination of elements affects teacher performance.

Researchers have argued that effective teachers increase student achievement scores (Nye, Konstantopoulos, & Hedges, 2004; Palardy & Rumberger, 2008), whereas others have highlighted the measurable differences between effective and ineffective teachers (Stronge, Ward, Tucker, & Hindman, 2008). More specifically, effective teachers have fewer classroom disruptions, have better classroom management skills, and exhibit better rapport with students than ineffective teachers. Additionally, effective teachers vary instructional strategies, have high student engagement, employ various levels of thinking when questioning students, and view the profession as a service to students (Popp et al., 2011).

sec.title: Incompetence
sec.p: It is estimated that 5% to 15% of the teacher workforce is incompetent (U.S. Department of Education, 1993; Yariv, 2004), yet the dismissal rate is less than 1% (Nixon, Packard, & Douvanis, 2010; Yariv, 2004) because “the expense of a dismissal, not to mention the risk of a lawsuit, makes school districts reluctant to embark on formal discharge proceedings” (Fossey, 1998, p. 61). The negative effects of incompetent teachers on student achievement are cumulative and have been found to be measurable even up to 3 years after initial student contact (Sanders & Rivers, 1996; Wright et al., 1997). Researchers argue that removing incompetent teachers would immediately improve student achievement in all schools; however, not confronting them sends the message to other teachers that evaluation is not a serious business (Chait, 2010; Wise et al., 1984).

Incompetent teachers display common traits. For example, Brieschke (1986) reported principals described incompetent teachers as individuals who continue to accumulate small mistakes, such as disregard for school norms, exhibit low commitment, develop poor student relationships, and have low student achievement. Phillips and Young (1997) reported principals identified excessive parent, student, and colleague complaints as evidence to support incompetency. Torff and Sessions (2005) found principals perceived weak classroom management skills and poor lesson implementation as significant factors in categorizing teachers as ineffective. Finally, Stronge (2002) argued that “the ultimate proof of teacher effectiveness is student results” (p. 65), inferring that lack of student progress was also an indicator of teacher ineffectiveness.

sec.title: Statutory definition of incompetence
sec.p: Grounds for terminating tenured teachers include immorality, misconduct, neglect of duty, good or just cause, insubordination, and incompetency (Alexander & Alexander, 2001). Although 31 states use incompetency as a grounds for remediation or termination (Tucker, 1997), its definition is usually quite vague causing school leaders to create their own definition (Painter, 2000). Essex (2012) defined incompetence as “inefficiency, a lack of skill, inadequate knowledge of subject manner, inability or unwillingness to teach the curricula, failure to work effectively with colleagues and parents, failure to maintain discipline, mismanagement in the classroom, and attitudinal deficiencies” (p. 255). Courts usually consider a host of factors when making a decision concerning incompetency (Alexander & Alexander, 2001), and teachers are rarely found incompetent by exhibiting one trait alone (Fischer, Schimmel & Kelly, 1999). Nixon, Packard, and Dam (2011) called this assessing teacher merit by looking at “a pattern of behavior rather than a single event” (p. 3).

In the end, because teachers have been awarded a certificate by the state and deemed competent, the burden of proof to dismiss incompetent teachers is on school leaders. As a result, proper evaluation, documentation, and adherence to deadlines are critical when proving incompetence within courts (Essex, 2012; Platt et al., 2000). Although labor intensive, when proper procedures are followed, courts will uphold the dismissal of incompetent teachers (Essex, 2012; Johnson v. Howell R-3 Board of Education, 1994).

sec.title: Strategies Used With Incompetent Teachers
sec.p: “One of the burdens of the principalship is the identification of educational mistakes among teachers and the development of mechanisms for addressing these mistakes” (Brieschke, 1986, p. 249). What these mechanisms look like differ from district to district, but the most common strategy used with incompetent teachers is attempting remediation through professional improvement or remediation plans (Bridges, 1992; Essex, 2012; Nixon et al., 2010). Professional improvement plans require principals to directly address deficiencies and create professional development plans with teachers to remedy weaknesses (Zepeda, 2007). However, the remediation process is difficult because of the lack of resolve of principals to be upfront with concerns (Nixon et al., 2010). In addition, some teachers who require remediation seldom take ownership of the plan which truly impacts improvement (Range et al., 2011).

Another strategy used by school leaders is to pressure incompetent teachers to resign, a maneuver Phillips and Young (1997) termed induced exit or out-counseling. Out-counseling might appeal to school leaders because they are able to avoid dismissal hearings, which if violated, may lead to legal challenges or grievances (Pratt, 1996; Stoelinga, 2011). Finally, transferring incompetent teachers to another school, assigning them a different role within the district, assigning them less challenging work, and moving them to noninstructional positions are also common administrative strategies (Chait, 2010; Platt et al., 2000).

sec.title: Barriers to Dismissing Incompetent Teachers
sec.p: Regardless of levels of teacher incompetency, school leaders are reluctant to remove ineffective teachers (Zirkel, 2010) and cite various barriers as deterrents to their dismissal (Coleman, Schroth, Molinaro, & Green, 2005; Menuey, 2005; Mock & Melnick, 1991; Painter, 2000; Phillips & Young, 1997). For example, a major barrier to the dismissal of incompetent teachers is the personal stress the process can inflict on school leaders (Wragg et al., 1999). Dismissal means making a decision that will financially affect teachers, and as a result, school leaders spend tremendous time mulling the ethics of the decision (Pratt, 1996). Nixon et al. (2010) described this hardship by stating, “The principal is made to feel as if she/he is on trial rather than the teacher’s performance” (p. 45). When faced with this extraordinary stress, many school leaders choose to ignore ineffective teachers (Bridges, 1992; Haefele, 1992; Painter, 2000; Zirkel, 2010).

The tremendous amount of bureaucratic hurdles that must be cleared in order to establish incompetency (Cooper et al., 2005; Stossel, 2006) creates another barrier. The process involves frequent observations, detailed documentation, and burden of proof on administrators to show a reasonable effort was made to remedy deficiencies (Brieschke, 1986; Essex, 20112; Haefele, 1992; Stoelinga, 2011). This laborious process is especially true for teachers who have acquired tenure. For example, Kersten (2006) found school board presidents viewed tenure as a roadblock to dismissing incompetent teachers because tenured teachers are required to have a hearing that requires copious amounts of time and money. Furthermore, there is no certainty results of the hearing will be successful (Nixon et al., 2010).

Teacher unions and legal expenses have also been reported as barriers to dismissing incompetent teachers (Chait, 2010; Nixon et al., 2011; Painter, 2000; Sowell, 2000; Stossel, 2006). For example, Painter (2000) found 25% of principals complained about the obstacles of unions and legality issues when collecting needed documentation to dismiss teachers. With regard to teacher unions, Coleman et al. (2005) stated that “teachers unions and associations play key roles in establishing the ground rules regarding the conditions under which teachers work, especially laws relating to teacher tenure, dismissal for cause, and due process” (pp. 226-227). Additionally, unions are sometimes responsible for defending teachers during dismissal hearings, which might cost school districts more than $200,000 in legal fees (Chait, 2010).

Still another barrier to the dismissal of incompetent teachers is the evaluation tools. Most evaluation tools require formal observations that are too infrequent and unfocused to provide constructive feedback to teachers (Haefele, 1992; Hinchey, 2010; Jacob & Lefgren, 2008; Kersten, 2006; Phillips & Young, 1997; Stoelinga, 2011; The New Teacher Project, 2010; Tucker, 1997; Yariv, 2004; Wise et al., 1984). Additionally, many evaluation instruments do not differentiate between incompetent and effective teachers (Nixon et al., 2011), and most school districts lack the staff and expertise to fully evaluate all certified employees with rigor and breadth (Chait, 2010). For example, Weisberg et al. (2010) reported that most evaluation procedures required two or fewer annual evaluations, each lasting 60 minutes or less, regardless of current job performance. Many evaluation tools require a single preplanned lesson in which teachers have prior knowledge that they will be observed, which skews observations (Marshal, 2009; Stoelinga, 2011). As a result, school leaders must depend less on evaluation instruments and more on formative supervision to detect incompetency (Brieschke, 1986; Earnshaw, Marchington, Ritchie, & Torrington, 2004; Wragg et al., 1999; Zepeda, 2007).

Finally, Pajak’s (2003) discussion on diverse teaching styles implies an additional barrier affecting the identification and dismissal of ineffective teachers: disconnect among “languages and communication dialects” (Pajak, 2003, p. vii). Unidentified cultural and linguistic diversity between teachers under scrutiny and principals attempting to guide teachers’ practice presents a frequently unrecognized barrier in two ways: (a) defining ineffective teachers and (b) communicating effectively with teachers regarding reasonable expectations for performance. In many cases, principals are not sensitive to “legitimate perspectives and practices [of teachers] that differ from their own preferred styles of perceiving, judging, and communicating about reality” (Pajak, 2003, p. 4). When this occurs, it becomes difficult for principals and teachers to reach a shared understanding of evaluation outcomes, making communication about the evaluation process meaningless (Stronge, n.d.).

sec.title: Context of the Study
sec.p: According to the 2010 Wyoming Education Summary compiled by the Wyoming Department of Education (WDE), Wyoming has 48 school districts, each of which has one superintendent. A total of 286 principals serve 354 Wyoming schools and elementary and middle (K-9) schools (274) outnumber high (9-12) schools (74) and K-12 (6) schools. Wyoming requires all teachers to be evaluated each year (National Council on Teacher Quality, 2010), which includes the following: (a) initial contract teachers who have taught in the same school district for 3 years or less and (b) continuing contact teachers who have taught more than 3 years in the same school district (The Education Laws of Wyoming Annotated, 2008).

During the 2011 Wyoming legislative session, legislators passed the Teacher Accountability Act requiring all Wyoming school districts to adopt certified personnel evaluation systems approved by the WDE (Memorandum No. 2011-048, 2011). An important component of this act was the requirement to use student achievement data to assess teacher competence. In the end, the Teacher Accountability Act requires teacher evaluation instruments to rate teachers as highly effective, effective, or ineffective. Teachers deemed ineffective would be targeted by school leaders for remediation, suspension, or termination.

Finally, the Wyoming Education Association (WEA) is the primary teacher union in the state with more than 6,300 members. With association membership, educators receive 1 million dollars in Educators Employment Liability (ELL), which protects them in job-related matters. Finally, WEA provides legal counsel for members who might encounter employment issues (WEA, n.d.).

sec.title: Research Method
sec.p: The goal of this study was to illuminate the perceptions of Wyoming school leaders concerning the traits of incompetent teachers, administrative strategies used with incompetent teachers, and barriers to their dismissal. Three research questions guided the inquiry:

list-item.p: Research Question 1: What are school leaders’ perceptions concerning the traits of incompetent teachers?
Research Question 2: What are school leaders’ perceptions about administrative strategies used with incompetent teachers?
Research Question 3: What are school leaders’ perceptions concerning barriers to dismissing incompetent teachers?

sec.p: The study was descriptive and used an online survey to measure school leaders’ perceptions. In April 2011, an e-mail with the link to the online survey was sent to all Wyoming school leaders (principals = 286; superintendents = 48). Up to two reminder e-mails were sent over a period of 2 weeks requesting school leaders to complete the survey.

sec.title: Instrument
sec.p: The instrument used in the data collection was a survey adapted with permission from a previous study about incompetent teachers (Menuey, 2005). Because Menuey’s study was conducted in another state and targeted only teachers’ perceptions, not all survey items were appropriate for this study. In the end, the wording of some items was changed and modified to reflect both Wyoming terminology and school leaders’ responsibilities. In its final version, the survey contained a total of 46 Likert-scaled items in three sections. The first section included 18 Likert-scaled items (1 = very uncommon to 4 = common) aimed to identify behaviors school leaders believed to be factors that contributed to teacher incompetence. The second section included 18 Likert-scaled items (1 = very uncommon to 4 = very common) and sought to identify strategies school districts used to deal with incompetent teachers. The third section, which included 10 Likert-scaled items (1 = no strength to 4 = high strength), aimed to identify what school leaders believed were the greatest barriers to dismissing incompetent teachers. The survey concluded by collecting demographic data about respondents along with one open-ended question in which school leaders were asked to estimate the number of incompetent teachers with whom they had worked in the past and to describe their traits.

Cronbach alpha coefficients were calculated in order to determine internal consistency for the instrument. The overall alpha level for all 46 Likert-scaled items was .76, which is an acceptable coefficient (George & Mallery, 2003). Reliability coefficients for the three separate sections were school leaders’ perceptions of traits of incompetent teachers (.86), administrative strategies used with incompetent teachers (.61), and barriers to dismissing incompetent teachers (.74). Content validity was also supported by the correspondence between literature on incompetent teachers and items on the survey, along with expert review.

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: Although not all Wyoming principals and superintendents responded to the survey, a significant sample provided perceptions about how they react to incompetent teachers. Of the 334 possible respondents, a total of 100 usable surveys were returned, a response rate of 30%. Seventy percent of the respondents were principals whereas 30% were superintendents. School configurations as reported by principals were (a) 40% supervised elementary schools, (b) 23% supervised middle schools, (c) 25% supervised high schools, and (d) 12% supervised K-12 campuses. Superintendents reported the average size of their districts was 1,527.71 students, with a range of 100 to 13,000. Respondents’ years of administrative experience averaged 13.74 years, with a range of 1 to 37 years.

sec.title: Data Analysis
sec.p: Three types of analysis were computed on the surveys. First, quantitative data were coded and analyzed descriptively for the purposes of summarizing the ratings for each Likert-scaled item on the survey (means and standards deviations). Second, independent-samples t tests were used to determine differences in means between principals and superintendents. Third, open-ended responses were coded into themes individually by two researchers and then collaboratively until 100% agreement about appropriate themes was reached (Jones, Torres, & Arminio, 2006). The findings of the study are presented in relation to the three research questions followed by a description of themes derived from the analysis of the open-ended item.

sec.title: School Leaders’ Perceptions of the Traits of Incompetent Teachers
sec.p: To answer Research Question 1, which asked what were school leaders’ perceptions about the traits of incompetent teachers, differences in means between school leaders (principals and superintendents) were compared using independent-samples t tests on the 18 Likert-scaled items (1 = very uncommon to 4 = very common) in Section 1 of the survey. Table 1 displays principals’ and superintendents’ responses concerning the traits of incompetent teachers. An overall significance level of .05 was used for t tests.

caption.p: School Leaders’ Perceptions of the Traits of Incompetent Teachers

tr.td: 5. Resistance to school or district initiatives
9. Behavior causing low morale among students

fn.p: Denotes a significant difference between principals and superintendents at the .05 level; scale ranges from 1 (very uncommon) to 4 (very common).

sec.p: Principals rated weak classroom management skills (M = 3.81), lack of lesson planning (M = 3.43), and weak communication with parents (M = 3.36) as the most common traits of incompetent teachers. Superintendents rated poor professional judgment (M = 3.57), weak communication with parents (M = 3.55), and weak classroom management skills (M = 3.53) as common traits of incompetent teachers.

Results of independent-samples t tests indicated superintendents agreed significantly more than principals that poor reading and writing skills were traits of incompetent teachers (t = −2.02, p < .04). There were no significant differences between principals and superintendents when comparing their views about the other traits of incompetent teachers.

sec.title: School Leaders’ Perceptions About the Administrative Strategies Used With Incompetent Teachers
sec.p: Research Question 2, which asked what were school leaders’ perceptions about the strategies used with incompetent teachers, was answered by 18 Likert-scaled items (1 = very uncommon to 4 = very common) in Section 2 of the survey. Table 2 displays principals’ and superintendents’ responses concerning the strategies used with incompetent teachers. An overall significance level of .05 was used for t tests.

caption.p: School Leaders’ Perceptions of Strategies Used With Incompetent Teachers

tr.td: 1. Provision with monetary settlement to leave/contract buy-out
7. Involuntary switch to another teaching assignment
10. Voluntary switch to another teaching assignment*
12. Involuntary transfer to another school in same district
13. Voluntary transfer to another school in same district
14. Increased workload to encourage teacher resignation
16. Involuntary switch to a non-teaching assignment
17. Voluntary switch to a non-teaching assignment

fn.p: Denotes a significant difference between principals and superintendents at the .05 level; scale ranges from 1 (very uncommon) to 4 (very common).

sec.p: Principals rated retirement (M = 2.87), counseling to leave the profession (M = 2.83), and remediation/improvement (M = 2.44) as the most common strategies used with incompetent teachers. Superintendents rated counseling to the leave the profession (M = 3.31), forced resignation (M = 2.45), and retirement (M = 2.39) as the most common strategies used with incompetent teachers.

Independent-samples t tests showed principals agreed significantly more than superintendents that retirement (t = 2.53, p < .01), voluntary switching incompetent teachers to another teaching assignment (t = 2.14, p < .04), and promoting incompetent teachers to central office positions (t = 2.04, p < .04) were strategies used with ineffective teachers. Conversely, superintendents agreed significantly more than principals that counseling to leave the profession (t = −2.75, p < .00) was a common strategy used with incompetent teachers.

sec.title: School Leaders’ Perceptions About the Barriers to Dismissing Incompetent Teachers
sec.p: Research Question 3, which asked what were school leaders’ perceptions about barriers to dismissing incompetent teachers, was answered by 10 Likert-scaled items (1 = no strength to 4 = high strength) in Section 3 of the survey. Table 3 displays principals’ and superintendents’ responses concerning the barriers to dismissing incompetent teachers. An overall significance level of .05 was used for t tests.

caption.p: School Leaders’ Perceptions of Barriers to Dismissing Incompetent Teachers

tr.td: 4. Protection of employee by professional association
5. Lack of support by superiors of principal*
7. Lack of strength of character by the principal*
8. Lack of skill by the principal to achieve dismissal*
9. Lack of support by school employees
10. Lack of support by the community*

fn.p: Denotes a significant difference between principals and superintendents at the .05 level; scale ranges from 1 (no strength) to 4 (high strength).

sec.p: Principals rated required administrative time (M = 2.86), protection of employee by professional association (M = 2.79), and legal and other expenses (M = 2.71) as barriers with strength when attempting to dismiss incompetent teachers. Superintendents rated unclear definition of incompetence (M = 2.60), protection of employee by professional association (M = 2.57), and lack of strength of character by the principal (M = 2.53) as barriers to dismissing incompetent teachers.

Results of the independent-samples t tests indicated that principals agreed significantly more than superintendents that legal and other expenses (t = 2.05, p < .04), required administrative time (t = 2.21, p < .03), and lack of support by superiors of the principal (t = 2.11, p < .04) were barriers to dismissing incompetent teachers. However, superintendents agreed significantly more than principals that lack of strength of character by the principal (t = −2.12, p < .04), lack of skill by the principal to achieve dismissal (t = −2.68, p < .00), and lack of support by the community (t = −2.15, p < .03) were barriers to dismissing incompetent teachers.

sec.title: School Leaders’ Perceptions About the Teacher Incompetency Problem
sec.p: One open-ended question provided school leaders an opportunity to estimate the number of incompetent teachers with whom they had worked with in the past and to describe their traits. Ninety-five school leaders responded to the question and indicated they had worked with an average of 8.44 incompetent teachers with a range of 2 to 50. School leaders first reinforced the notion that defining truly incompetent teachers was difficult. Several school leaders believed incompetent teachers were not a rampant problem; marginal teaching was much more common. School leaders stated they out-counseled incompetent teachers from the profession and most incompetent teachers they identified were close to retirement.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Identifying the causes of teacher ineffectiveness is important for whole school reform as well as when designing school accountability systems (Darling-Hammond & Snyder, 2000; Futernick, 2010; Torff & Sessions, 2005). This study used an online survey to measure school leaders’ (principals and superintendents) perceptions about the traits of incompetent teachers, strategies school leaders and districts use to deal with incompetent teachers, and barriers to dismissing incompetent teachers. More specifically, the authors wanted to know how school leaders’ perceptions about incompetency issues differed based on role as either a principal or superintendent, a focus seldom found in the literature (Last & Murphy, 1998; Mock & Melnick, 1991; Nixon et al., 2010; Painter, 2000; Tucker, 1997; Wragg et al., 1999), and we argue our findings are valuable within this line of research. However, the results of this study are limited in that the response rate to the survey was 30% and included only Wyoming school leaders. Nevertheless, results support previous inquires about teacher incompetency issues (Nixon et al., 2011; Wragg et al., 1999; Yariv, 2004), yet highlight unique variations in how principals and superintendents differ in their views about incompetent teachers.

Overall, school leaders indicated they had worked with an average of 8.44 incompetent teachers, higher than other studies (Painter, 2000; Tucker, 1997; Yariv, 2004). Additionally, within open-ended responses, school leaders identified mediocre teachers, those who are competent but add little to the profession, as a problem, which concurs with other researchers (Platt et al., 2000; Wragg et al., 1999). These perceptions are consistent with Jacob and Lefgren (2008) and Yariv (2004), who found principals can easily identify the best and worst teachers, yet have difficulty identifying those who are mediocre.

With regard to the traits of incompetent teachers, both principals and superintendents perceived weak classroom management skills as a common trait of incompetent teachers, a finding that concurs with other studies (Nixon et al., 2011; Torff & Sessions, 2005; Wragg et al., 1999; Yariv, 2004). In fact, Stronge et al. (2011) reported the primary discrepancy between effective and ineffective teachers was their ability to manage classrooms. Additionally, our findings support Wragg et al. (1999), who have found school leaders viewed weak communication with parents as a common trait of incompetent teachers. Finally, superintendents agreed significantly more than principals that poor reading and writing skills were traits of incompetent teachers. In interpreting this finding, Torff and Sessions (2005) classified poor reading and writing skills as deficiencies in teachers’ content knowledge and not a pedagogical limitation. If this is accurate, our findings suggest superintendents believed content knowledge limitations were a stronger source of teacher incompetency than principals.

Both principals and superintendents believed counseling to leave the profession and retirement were common administrative strategies used with incompetent teachers, findings that concur with Wragg et al. (1999). Specifically, principals viewed counseling to leave the profession as a strategy used with incompetent teachers significantly more than superintendents. For principals, out-counseling might be seen as an attractive administrative strategy used with ineffective teachers because school leaders can avoid full dismissal hearings. As discussed previously, formal dismissal procedures require copious amounts of both administrative time and documentation and typically end in a hearing, in which principals must present evidence that supports their dismissal recommendation.

Finally, we argue that the most significant findings of this study highlight the similarities and differences in how principals and superintendents viewed the barriers to dismissing incompetent teachers. First, both principals and superintendents viewed protection of incompetent teachers by professional associations as a barrier with some strength. This finding aligns with other researchers who have identified teacher professional organizations as an obstacle to removing ineffective teachers (Chait, 2010; Painter, 2000; Sowell, 2000). Although Wyoming is a right work state in which teachers have the flexibility to decide whether they support teacher unions (National Right to Work, n.d.), school leaders in this study believed WEA was an obstacle when addressing incompetent teachers.

Second, principals’ and superintendents’ attitudes about the barriers to dismissing incompetent teachers differed in notable ways. Principals perceived lack of support by their superiors as a stronger barrier to dismissing incompetent teachers than superintendents. What this support for principals may look like differs based on the circumstances of the teacher’s performance (Brieschke, 1986; Painter, 2000). To make their efforts worth the time and stress, principals attempting to remove ineffective teachers from the classroom require the support of superintendents and boards of education (Bridges, 1992).

Finally, our results concur with Wise et al. (1984) in that superintendents viewed lack of resolve and skill by principals as barriers to removing incompetent teachers. Superintendents must adopt a conviction that their primary duty is to develop principals into instructional leaders and devote considerable time discussing supervision and evaluation issues with principals, including addressing incompetent teachers (Fink & Resnick, 2001; Waters & Marzano, 2008).

sec.title: Recommendations
sec.p: Based on the findings of this study, we make three recommendations regarding supervision and evaluation procedures in Wyoming. However, these recommendations can be applied to any state, school, or district that is revamping their teacher evaluation mechanisms. First, evaluation instruments adopted by Wyoming school districts to comply with reform efforts should rely on multiple data sources regarding teacher effectiveness and exhibit four characteristics, namely, propriety, utility, feasibility, and accuracy (Stronge, n.d.). Because teacher evaluation reform has been a focus of Wyoming policy makers and the WDE (Memorandum No. 2011-048, 2011) in recent years, it is important for Wyoming school districts to understand incompetency is not solely based on student achievement scores, but may be attributed to multiple factors (Fischer et al., 1999; Nixon et al., 2011). In the end, the evaluation of incompetent teachers is a complex process (Painter, 2000) and should hinge less on subjective judgments about teacher performance and more on standardized instruments. This recommendation is supported by the finding that Wyoming school leaders acknowledged incompetent teachers were a problem in schools.

Second, Wyoming school leaders and the WEA must work together to ensure that both teachers and administrators understand the definition of ineffective teachers as outlined by the Teacher Accountability Act. Additionally, school leaders should seek out WEA’s assistance in providing professional development to principals so they acquire the skills to addresses incompetent teachers in a fair and legal manner. This recommendation is based on the finding that school leaders perceived the WEA as an organization that protects ineffective teachers and was a barrier to their dismissal.

Third, and most importantly, the capacity of preservice and practicing principals must be developed so that they are prepared to be instructional leaders equipped with the skills necessary to address ineffective teachers. Wyoming school districts must provide training to principals concerning proper documentation, available support from superiors, and legal ramifications when building a case against incompetency (Chait, 2010; Hinchey, 2010; The New Teacher Project, 2010). Additionally, university principal preparation programs should partner with Wyoming superintendents to determine instructional leadership skills principals lack. Principal preparation programs must work to ensure principals are “instructional leaders who have the skills and knowledge set that is correlated with increased student achievement” (Waters & Marzano, 2008, p. 13). School leaders must be trained in how to provide feedback that instigates instructional change and how to follow through with remediation plans for struggling teachers (Chait, 2010; Range et al., 2011). This recommendation is based on the finding that there were significant differences in how principals and superintendents viewed barriers to dismissing incompetent teachers.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: School leaders play a significant role in the socialization of teachers to the profession and are charged with ensuring they are competent (Brieschke, 1986; Brown & Wynn, 2009). This pressure will not likely vanish as educational reform and accountability efforts place the onus of student success directly on teacher effectiveness. In order to fairly evaluate all teachers and remove incompetent teachers from the system, school leaders must be able to identify ineffective teachers, create a plan to remediate them, and identify barriers that make their dismissal difficult. Most importantly, school leaders must understand effective teacher evaluation rests on their ability to adopt technically sound evaluation instruments, provide adequate training for all supervisors, and intervene immediately if they sense teachers are ineffective.

As with other studies, results from this study generate more avenues for research. This study did not differentiate school leaders’ perceptions of incompetency between initial contract and tenured teachers. Because school leaders differentiated between mediocre and incompetent teachers, additional research about school leaders’ definitions concerning mediocre teachers would be valuable. Additionally, this study did not measure the perceptions of principals, those on the front-lines when managing incompetent teachers, as to what direct supports they need to make the task manageable. Finally, because this study relied mainly on quantitative data to draw conclusions, a qualitative analysis around the problem would be a beneficial and reinforce our findings.

fn.label: Declaration of Conflicting Interests
fn.p: The author(s) declared no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: The author(s) received no financial support for the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.

bio.title: Bios
bio.p: Bret G. Range is an assistant professor in educational leadership at the University of Wyoming. His research interests include teacher supervision and evaluation and grade retention.

Heather E. Duncan is an associate professor and coordinates the educational leadership program at the University of Wyoming. Her research interests focus on profession development for principals, mentoring, rural education, and online learning.

Susan Day Scherz is an assistant professor in educational leadership at the University of Wyoming and teaches graduate educational leadership courses. Earlier years as a K-12 teacher, director/associate superintendent of an educational consortium and school/district administrator in traditional and non-traditional settings were spent primarily in rural areas of western and south-central Arizona.
Courtney A. Haines is an assistant professor in educational research at the University of Wyoming. Her research interests include use of mixed methods and student achievement.
